articles.headline: A Clash of Cultures, Averted
articles.snippet: The differing financial styles of Bank of America and MBNA come together, and, mostly, it works.
articles.abstract: The differing financial styles of Bank of America and MBNA come together, and, mostly, it works.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Bank of America announced its $35 billion acquisition of MBNA in summer 2005, many people questioned whether it would work.

articles.headline: Left Holding the Bag in the Land of Fast Food
articles.snippet: A franchise in a popular restaurant chain can be profitable. But when food-borne illness strikes, it can be financially risky.
articles.abstract: A franchise in a popular restaurant chain can be profitable. But when food-borne illness strikes, it can be financially risky.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANCHISE owners lie awake at night thinking about customers like Stephen Minnis.

articles.headline: Anglicans Rebuke U.S. Branch on Blessing Same-Sex Unions
articles.snippet: The Episcopal Church was told to ban blessings of same-sex unions or risk a reduced role in the denomination.
articles.abstract: The Episcopal Church was told to ban blessings of same-sex unions or risk a reduced role in the denomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing a possible churchwide schism, the Anglican Communion yesterday gave its Episcopal branch in the United States less than eight months to ban blessings of same-sex unions or risk a reduced role in the world’s third-largest Christian denomination.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Merger Would End Satellite Radio’s Rivalry
articles.snippet: The planned $13 billion merger of the nation’s two satellite radio services, Sirius and XM, is sure to raise antitrust issues.
articles.abstract: The planned $13 billion merger of the nation’s two satellite radio services, Sirius and XM, is sure to raise antitrust issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s two satellite radio services, Sirius and XM, announced plans yesterday to merge, a move that would end their costly competition for radio personalities and subscribers but that is also sure to raise antitrust issues.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Iraqi Militants Launch Attack on U.S. Outpost
articles.snippet: In a rare coordinated assault on a U.S. combat outpost north of Baghdad, insurgents killed two American soldiers and wounded at least 17 more.
articles.abstract: In a rare coordinated assault on a U.S. combat outpost north of Baghdad, insurgents killed two American soldiers and wounded at least 17 more.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 19 — In a rare coordinated assault on an American combat outpost north of Baghdad, suicide bombers drove one or more cars laden with explosives into the compound on Monday, while other insurgents opened fire in the ensuing chaos, according to witnesses and the American military. Two American soldiers were killed and at least 17 were wounded.

articles.headline: Guilt-Free Pollution. Or Is It?
articles.snippet: Pop stars, chief executives and politicians vaunt how they offset carbon emissions by planting trees or investing in renewable energy projects.
articles.abstract: Pop stars, chief executives and politicians vaunt how they offset carbon emissions by planting trees or investing in renewable energy projects.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 19 — Two years ago, Sami Grover, an environmentally minded Englishman, vowed to take his last trip by airplane. Then a summer romance in North Carolina turned into a long-distance love affair — and then into months of busy trans-Atlantic travel.

articles.headline: Revamping at Airbus Is Delayed
articles.snippet: Pressure from European governments has blocked an overhaul plan for the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company.
articles.abstract: Pressure from European governments has blocked an overhaul plan for the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Feb. 19 — Mounting pressure from European governments has blocked a long-awaited overhaul plan for the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company that is expected to result in thousands of lost jobs at the company’s troubled Airbus unit.

articles.headline: Many Are Eager to See Data on Chrysler
articles.snippet: Rival auto companies and other potential suitors are eager to look at Chrysler’s books, now that it may be up for sale.
articles.abstract: Rival auto companies and other potential suitors are eager to look at Chrysler’s books, now that it may be up for sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, Feb. 19 — Not since Jürgen E. Schrempp announced that he was stepping down 18 months ago has there been this much interest in DaimlerChrysler stock.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: JetBlue Begins Reimbursing Stranded Passengers
articles.snippet: The company will begin payments ranging from $25 toward a future flight to a round-trip ticket to passengers kept waiting by the airline’s own mistakes.
articles.abstract: The company will begin payments ranging from $25 toward a future flight to a round-trip ticket to passengers kept waiting by the airline’s own mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it would immediately begin paying penalties, ranging from $25 toward a future flight to a round-trip ticket, to passengers kept waiting by the airline’s own mistakes.

articles.headline: North Africa Feared as Staging Ground for Terror
articles.snippet: A brutal Algerian group with a long history of violence is suspected of organizing a new force for jihad in Tunisia.
articles.abstract: A brutal Algerian group with a long history of violence is suspected of organizing a new force for jihad in Tunisia.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The plan, hatched for months in the arid mountains of North Africa, was to attack the American and British Embassies here. It ended in a series of gun battles in January that killed a dozen militants and left two Tunisian security officers dead.
